events.name: D-Day (Operation Overlord)
events.description: Allied invasion of Normandy begins. The largest seaborne invasion in history.
events.summary: The Normandy landings were the landing operations and associated airborne operations on 6 June 1944 of the Allied invasion of Normandy in Operation Overlord during the Second World War. Codenamed Operation Neptune and often referred to as D-Day, it is the largest seaborne invasion in history. The operation began the liberation of France, and the rest of Western Europe, and laid the foundations for the Allied victory on the Western Front.
key_facts: 156,000 Allied troops landed on first day
5 beaches: Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno, Sword
events.map_svg:
<svg viewBox="0 0 300 200" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <style>

      .annotation { fill: none; stroke: #8b4513; stroke-width: 1.5; opacity: 0.6; }
      .river { fill: none; stroke: #6ba3d6; stroke-width: 2; }
      .zone { fill: #c0392b; opacity: 0.2; }
    </style>
  </defs>
  <rect class="water" width="300" height="200"/>
  <path class="land" d="M0,120 Q30,100 60,110 Q90,95 120,105 Q150,90 180,100 Q210,85 240,95 Q270,80 300,90 L300,200 L0,200 Z"/>
  <line class="annotation" x1="150" y1="40" x2="150" y2="80" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  <circle class="marker" cx="40" cy="105" r="4"/>
  <text class="label" x="46" y="109">Utah</text>
  <circle class="marker" cx="85" cy="100" r="4"/>
  <text class="label" x="91" y="104">Omaha</text>
  <circle class="marker" cx="140" cy="95" r="4"/>
  <text class="label" x="146" y="99">Gold</text>
  <circle class="marker" cx="195" cy="90" r="4"/>
  <text class="label" x="201" y="94">Juno</text>
  <circle class="marker" cx="250" cy="85" r="4"/>
  <text class="label" x="256" y="89">Sword</text>
  <text class="title" x="10" y="15">D-Day Landings</text>
</svg>

events.name: Edgar lands in France
events.description: Edgar arrives at Crepon gun site at 12:45am, D-Day+1. First night on French soil.

events.name: Bombing of Caen
events.description: Over 500 Lancasters and Halifaxes bomb Caen. Edgar witnessed this 'great sight' from his position.
events.summary: Operation Charnwood was an Anglo-Canadian offensive that took place from 8 to 9 July 1944, during the Battle for Caen, part of the larger Operation Overlord in the Second World War. The operation was intended to capture the German-occupied city of Caen, which was an important objective for the Allies during the opening stages of Overlord. It was also hoped that the attack would forestall the transfer of German armoured units from the Anglo-Canadian sector to the American sector to the west, where an offensive was being prepared. The British and Canadians advanced on a broad front and by the evening of the second day had taken Caen up to the Orne and Odon rivers.
events.map_svg:
<svg viewBox="0 0 300 200" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <style>
      .water { fill: #b8d4e8; }
      .land { fill: #e8e4d9; }
      .marker { fill: #8b4513; }

      .title { font-family: Georgia, serif; font-size: 11px; font-weight: bold; fill: #2c3e50; }
      .annotation { fill: none; stroke: #8b4513; stroke-width: 1.5; opacity: 0.6; }
      .river { fill: none; stroke: #6ba3d6; stroke-width: 2; }
      .zone { fill: #c0392b; opacity: 0.2; }
    </style>
  </defs>
  <rect class="water" width="300" height="200"/>
  <path class="land" d="M0,0 L300,0 L300,200 L0,200 Z"/>

  <text class="label" x="156" y="104">Caen</text>
  <circle class="marker" cx="80" cy="60" r="4"/>
  <text class="label" x="86" y="64">Crepon</text>
  <text class="title" x="10" y="15">Operation Charnwood</text>
</svg>

events.name: Liberation of Cherbourg
events.description: Major port of Cherbourg captured by US forces, providing crucial supply capabilities.
events.summary: The Battle of Cherbourg was part of the Battle of Normandy during World War II. It was fought immediately after the successful Allied landings on 6 June 1944. Allied troops, mainly American, isolated and captured the fortified port, which was considered vital to the campaign in Western Europe, in a hard-fought, month-long campaign.
key_facts: Port captured by US VII Corps

</svg>

events.name: Falaise Pocket closes
events.description: German forces trapped and destroyed in the Falaise Pocket, ending the Battle of Normandy.
events.summary: The Falaise pocket or battle of the Falaise pocket was the decisive engagement of the Battle of Normandy in the Second World War. Allied forces formed a pocket around Falaise, Calvados, in which German Army Group B, consisting of the 7th Army and the Fifth Panzer Army, were encircled by the Western Allies. The battle resulted in the destruction of most of Army Group B west of the Seine, which opened the way to Paris and the Franco-German border.

events.name: Liberation of Paris
events.description: Paris liberated after four years of German occupation.
events.summary: The Liberation of Paris was a battle that took place during World War II from 19 August 1944 until the German garrison surrendered the French capital on 25 August 1944. Paris had been occupied by Nazi Germany since the signing of the Armistice of 22 June 1940, after which the Wehrmacht occupied northern and western France.

events.name: Edgar leaves Normandy
events.description: 200-mile journey from Crepon through devastated Falaise to Amiens.

events.name: Liberation of Brussels
events.description: Brussels liberated by British forces.
events.summary: The Liberation of Belgium from German occupation began on 2 September 1944 when Allied forces entered the province of Hainaut and was completed on 4 February 1945 with the liberation of the village of Krewinkel. The liberation came after four years of German-occupied rule. The Belgian government was returned to power on 8 September 1944 after Allied forces had captured Brussels four days earlier.
key_facts: Part of the rapid Allied advance
events.map_svg:

  <text class="title" x="10" y="15">Liberation of Brussels</text>
</svg>

events.name: Liberation of Antwerp
events.description: Antwerp liberated, though the port would not be usable until the Scheldt was cleared.
events.summary: Antwerp was liberated on 4 September 1944 by the British 11th Armoured Division. The port facilities were captured nearly intact, but the city could not be used for shipping until the Scheldt estuary was cleared of German forces. The port would become the most important Allied supply hub after finally opening in late November.
key_facts: Could not be used until Scheldt cleared
events.map_svg:

events.name: Bombing of Calais
events.description: Edgar watched Lancasters and Halifaxes bombing Calais from Boulogne with no opposition.

events.name: Edgar's birthday in Belgium
events.description: Edgar arrives in Bruges on his birthday despite terrible weather.

events.name: Battle of the Scheldt
events.description: Allied campaign to open shipping route to Antwerp. Edgar's unit fired at German positions at Knokke.
events.summary: The Battle of the Scheldt in World War II was a series of military operations to open up the Scheldt river between Antwerp and the North Sea for shipping, so that Antwerp's port could be used to supply the Allies in north-west Europe. The operations were carried out by the First Canadian Army, with assistance from Polish and British units which had been attached. The action was under the acting command of the First Canadian's Lieutenant-General Guy Simonds. The battle took place in the vicinity of the Scheldt river in northern Belgium and southwestern Netherlands from 2 October to 8 November 1944.

  <text class="title" x="10" y="15">Battle of the Scheldt</text>
</svg>

events.name: Edgar arrives at Zuid Beveland
events.description: Gun position on a bleak dyke in front of the sea. Very cold winter ahead.

events.name: Battle of the Bulge begins
events.description: Last major German offensive on the Western Front.
events.summary: The Battle of the Bulge, also known as the Ardennes Offensive or Unternehmen Wacht am Rhein, was the last major German offensive campaign on the Western Front during the Second World War, taking place from 16 December 1944 to 25 January 1945. It was launched through the densely forested Ardennes region of eastern Belgium and northern Luxembourg. The offensive was intended to stop Allied use of the Belgian port of Antwerp and to split the Allied lines, allowing the Germans to encircle and destroy each of the four Allied armies and force the western Allies to negotiate a peace treaty in the Axis powers' favor.

  <text class="label" x="86" y="64">St. Vith</text>
  <text class="title" x="10" y="15">Battle of the Bulge</text>
</svg>

events.name: Battle of the Bulge ends
events.description: German offensive repulsed with heavy losses on both sides.
events.summary: The Battle of the Bulge, also known as the Ardennes Offensive or Unternehmen Wacht am Rhein, was the last major German offensive campaign on the Western Front during the Second World War, taking place from 16 December 1944 to 25 January 1945. It was launched through the densely forested Ardennes region of eastern Belgium and northern Luxembourg. The offensive was intended to stop Allied use of the Belgian port of Antwerp and to split the Allied lines, allowing the Germans to encircle and destroy each of the four Allied armies and force the western Allies to negotiate a peace treaty in the Axis powers' favor.

events.name: Edgar's first leave
events.description: Long-awaited leave to see Winnie. Hard seats and no heating on the train.

events.name: 48-hour leave in Brussels
events.description: Stay at the Albert Hotel with conducted tour of the city. V-1 air raid warnings.

events.name: Crossing of the Rhine
events.description: Allied forces cross the Rhine River into the German heartland.
events.summary: Operation Plunder was a military operation to cross the Rhine on the night of 23 March 1945, launched by the 21st Army Group under Field Marshal Bernard Montgomery. The crossing of the river was at Rees, Wesel, and south of the river Lippe by the British Second Army under Lieutenant General Miles Dempsey, and the United States Ninth Army under Lieutenant General William H. Simpson.

  <text class="title" x="10" y="15">Operation Plunder</text>
</svg>

events.name: Cease Firing order
events.description: Edgar's unit receives Cease Firing order. End of AA operations.

events.name: VE Day
events.description: Victory in Europe. Edgar witnessed celebrations at Kapelle - sirens sounded after midnight.
events.summary: Victory in Europe Day is the day celebrating the formal acceptance by the Allies of World War II of Nazi Germany's unconditional surrender of its armed forces on Tuesday, 8 May 1945; it marked the official surrender of all German military operations.

  <circle class="marker" cx="250" cy="100" r="4"/>

  <text class="title" x="10" y="15">Victory in Europe</text>
</svg>

events.name: Ransacking of collaborators' houses
events.description: Edgar witnessed crowds ransacking the houses of Nazi collaborators at Kapelle.

events.name: Edgar leaves for Germany
events.description: Journey to Berlin through devastated German cities. Wesel and Munster were 'heaps of rubble'.

events.name: Berlin Victory Parade
events.description: Allied victory parade through Berlin. Other regiments practiced while Edgar's unit built cooking places.
events.summary: The Berlin Victory Parade of 1945 was held by the Allies of World War II on 7 September 1945 in Berlin, the capital of the defeated Germany, shortly after the end of World War II. The four participating countries were the Soviet Union, the United States, the United Kingdom, and France.
events.map_svg:

  <circle class="marker" cx="150" cy="100" r="4"/>
  <text class="label" x="156" y="104">Berlin</text>
  <circle class="marker" cx="120" cy="80" r="4"/>
  <text class="label" x="126" y="84">Brandenburg</text>
  <text class="title" x="10" y="15">Berlin Victory Parade</text>
</svg>

events.name: Edgar arrives in Berlin
events.description: Final posting. Best bed in his army career, but city in ruins with 'whiff of dead people'.

events.name: Japan surrenders (VJ Day)
events.description: World War II officially ends with Japanese surrender.
events.summary: Victory over Japan Day is the day on which Imperial Japan surrendered in World War II, in effect bringing the war to an end. The term has been applied to both of the days on which the initial announcement of Japan's surrender was made – 15 August 1945, in Japan, and because of time zone differences, 14 August 1945 – as well as to 2 September 1945, when the surrender document was signed, officially ending World War II.
events.map_svg:
<svg viewBox="0 0 300 200" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <style>
      .water { fill: #b8d4e8; }
      .land { fill: #e8e4d9; }
      .marker { fill: #8b4513; }
      .label { font-family: Georgia, serif; font-size: 10px; fill: #333; }
      .title { font-family: Georgia, serif; font-size: 11px; font-weight: bold; fill: #2c3e50; }
      .annotation { fill: none; stroke: #8b4513; stroke-width: 1.5; opacity: 0.6; }
      .river { fill: none; stroke: #6ba3d6; stroke-width: 2; }
      .zone { fill: #c0392b; opacity: 0.2; }
    </style>
  </defs>
  <rect class="water" width="300" height="200"/>
  <path class="land" d="M50,0 L280,0 Q290,50 300,60 L300,200 L0,200 L0,100 L30,100 L35,60 Q40,30 50,0 Z"/>
  <path class="water" d="M0,0 L50,0 Q40,30 35,60 L30,100 L0,100 Z M280,0 L300,0 L300,60 Q290,50 280,40 Z"/>
  <circle class="marker" cx="150" cy="100" r="4"/>
  <text class="label" x="156" y="104">Europe</text>
  <text class="title" x="10" y="15">VJ Day</text>
</svg>

events.name: Edgar leaves Berlin for demob
events.description: Final journey home begins. Left Berlin Transit Camp at 7:40am.

events.name: Edgar arrives home
events.description: Arrived home at 4:30am after long journey via Dover, Reading, Hereford, and Crewe.

metadata.notes: Timeline events derived from Edgar Hopkins' WW2 diary and historical sources. Dates cross-referenced with diary text where possible.
